contextId.glQuote: my son

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here messages that do not come true are spoken of as if they fell to the ground. This can be stated positively. contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of money that people would give Samuel's sons as if it were a person or animal running away from Samuel's sons, and he speaks of Samuel's sons as if they were physically chasing that person or animal. contextId.glQuote: chased after dishonest gain

contextId.glQuote: Israel had become a rotten smell to the Philistines

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Philistines implied that the Hebrews had been hiding in holes in the ground like animals. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the obligation to obey an oath is spoken of as if the people were bound with ropes. Alternate translation: "commanded that the people obey his oath" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: Saul not obeying Yahweh is spoken of as if Saul had physically turned away from walking behind God. Alternate translation: "he has stopped following me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he has turned back from following me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "in your own opinion" or "in your judgment" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in your own sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sight" refers to Yahweh's thoughts or opinion. Alternate translation: "what Yahweh considers to be evil" or "what is evil in Yahweh's judgement" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "see" means to evaluate something. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh does not see as man sees

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here anger is spoken of as if it were a fire that could be kindled. Alternate translation: "Eliab became angry with David" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Eliab's anger was kindled against David

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a dog represents a small animal that a person can easily kill. The word "sticks" refers to David's staff and shows Goliath's opinion that it is not a good weapon. Goliath uses this question to accuse David of insulting him. Alternate translation: "You insult me by coming at me with mere sticks as if I were just a dog!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Am I a dog, that you come to me with sticks?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Goliath speaks of killing David and leaving his body on the ground for the animals to eat it as if he were to give David's body to the animals. Alternate translation: "I will kill you, and the birds of the heavens and the beasts of the field will eat your body" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will give your flesh to the birds of the heavens and to the beasts of the field

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of leading the Israelites in killing the Philistines and leaving their bodies on the ground for the animals to eat them as if he were to give their bodies to the animals. Alternate translation: "We Israelites will kill the Philistine army, and the birds of the heavens and the wild beasts of the earth will eat them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will give the dead bodies ... to the birds ... and to the wild beasts of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Very close friendship is spoken of as if it were binding together the souls of two people. This can be stated in active form. contextId.glQuote: the soul of Jonathan was bound to the soul of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "in the eyes of" and "in the sight of" mean the same thing. The opinion of the people is spoken of as something that they view as either good or bad. contextId.occurrenceNote: Harming someone is spoken of as if it were placing one's hand on that person. Here, Saul is referring to killing David. contextId.occurrenceNote: Harming someone is spoken of as if it were placing one's hand on that person. Here, Saul is referring to killing David. contextId.glQuote: if I have found favor in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks as if evil and treason were physical objects he could hold in his hand. Here "hand" represents a person acting or doing something. contextId.glQuote: After a dead dog

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "flea" is a metaphor for a person whom others do not consider important. Alternate translation: "You are pursuing a person who is as unimportant as a flea" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: After a flea

contextId.occurrenceNote: Saul speaks as if David were his son to show David that he loves him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer writes as if a voice were something a person could lift up with his hands. Alternate translation: "wept loudly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: "may you be pleased with my young men" or "may you consider my young men favorably" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: David's men were like a wall around a city that protects the people in the city from their enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
